channel.title: 经济学人
channel.description: 这是一个追踪经济学人news的种子

item.title: @john_hooper与乔治亚-梅洛尼（Giorgia Meloni）党内和党外人士对话，揭示奇幻文学与政治之间的联系。
item.description:
For right-wing Italians J.R.R Tolkien’s tales provide an inspirational ethos and offer “myth, community, honour, sacrifice”.@john_hooper talks to those in and around Giorgia Meloni’s party to uncover the connection between fantasy literature and politicshttps://t.co/VRBRm4MDhh

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 25, 2024

item.title: 意大利极右翼所钟爱的幻想作品都有以个人主义叛逆者为主角的叙事。在这些故事中，只有少数开明人士才能看清现实。摘自《1843》杂志
item.description:
The fantasy works beloved of the Italian far-right share narratives featuring individualistic rebels. In these stories, only an enlightened few can see reality clearly. From 1843 magazine https://t.co/IFJ0VQE1q3

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 25, 2024

item.title: 英国财政大臣杰里米-亨特（Jeremy Hunt）即将提交大选前的最后一份预算。他的后座议员要求减税，但资金紧张。怎么办？以下是一位假想的财政部官员的坦诚建议 👇
item.description:
Jeremy Hunt, Britain’s chancellor, will soon present what should be the last budget before the general election. His backbenchers are demanding tax cuts, but money is tight. What to do? Here’s the frank advice of an imaginary Treasury official https://t.co/fNoxscFP1i 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 25, 2024

item.title: 反对党领袖阿列克谢-纳瓦尔尼上个月写道："普京主义国家不可能持久。"总有一天，我们会发现，他已经不复存在了"👇。
item.description:
Alexei Navalny didn’t just defy Putin—he showed up his depravity.

“The Putinist state cannot last,” the opposition leader wrote last month. “One day we’ll look over, and he will be gone” https://t.co/n7BIOVkXvO 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 25, 2024

item.title: 数十年的吝啬使欧洲的防务付出了代价：整个欧洲大陆的武装力量都处于令人遗憾的状态。在大多数情况下，即使将国内生产总值的 2% 用于国防也是不够的👇。
item.description:
Decades of miserliness have taken a toll on Europe’s defences: armed forces across the continent are in a sorry state.

In most cases even spending 2% of GDP on defence will not be enough https://t.co/HDsyPWNRN4 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 25, 2024

item.title: 刚果 M23 叛乱运动有可能引发地区战争。最近，炮弹落在了戈马市外的流离失所者营地。前几次冲突的重演是一个令人担忧的前景👇。
item.description:
Congo’s M23 rebellion risks sparking regional war.

Fighting has already inflicted a heavy toll. Lately, artillery shells have been landing in camps for displaced people outside the city of Goma. A repeat of previous conflicts is an alarming prospect https://t.co/P4xW19bIu6 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 25, 2024

item.title: 感染并非引发长期慢性病的唯一原因。发现感染后疾病之间的相似之处可能会带来更好的治疗👇。
item.description:
Long covid is not the only chronic condition triggered by infection. Finding similarities between post-infectious illnesses could lead to better treatments https://t.co/997q7MnTX3 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 25, 2024

item.title: 石油和天然气公司表现出的兴趣表明，电气化可能是净化工业的答案。如果连它的天敌都能看到它的价值，那么它的前景一定是光明的 👇。
item.description:
One indication that electrification may be the answer to cleaning up industry is the interest shown by oil and gas companies. If even its natural enemies can see its worth, the prospects must be decent https://t.co/DsPxKpqSNb 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 25, 2024

item.title: 到 2023 年 4 月，俄罗斯因入侵乌克兰而损失的士兵人数超过了 1945 年以来历次战争的总和。到 2024 年 1 月，死亡人数大约翻了一番。这五张图表显示了有多少俄罗斯士兵被送上了死亡之路👇。
item.description:
By April 2023 Russia had lost more soldiers by invading Ukraine than it had in all its combined previous wars since 1945. By January 2024 deaths had roughly doubled. These five charts show how many Russian soldiers have been sent to their deaths https://t.co/1bCDBTSWHq 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 25, 2024

item.title: 推翻推迟塞内加尔选举的总统令是塞内加尔法官表现出的骨气，值得欢迎。但是，在宪法秩序和法治得到更加一致的执行之前，民主仍将面临风险👇。
item.description:
The striking down of a presidential decree to postpone Senegal’s election is a welcome display of spine from its judges.

But until constitutional order and rule of law become more consistently enforced, democracy will remain at risk https://t.co/U4pWwyB3mP 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 25, 2024

item.title: Leo Vardiashvili 的处女作《大森林的艰难》探讨了格鲁吉亚动荡不安的历史。引人入胜的散文、悲喜交加的情节和刻画细腻的人物形象让读者流连忘返，直到旅程结束 👇。
item.description:
Leo Vardiashvili’s debut novel, “Hard by a Great Forest”, explores Georgia’s troubled history. Compelling prose, tragicomic episodes and well-drawn characters keep the reader on board until the journey’s end https://t.co/A0tqISvd21 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 25, 2024

item.title: 乍一看，俄罗斯的经济欣欣向荣：商店里名牌商品琳琅满目，狂欢者在热闹的舞池中尽情狂欢。但在幕后，一切并不那么光明👇。
item.description:
At first glance Russia’s economy is thriving: shops bristle with designer goods and revellers party on heaving dancefloors. But behind the scenes things aren’t so bright https://t.co/GOJTkEQMvf 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 25, 2024

item.title: 如何不制作 PowerPoint 幻灯片的示例 👇
item.description:
An example of how not to make a PowerPoint slide https://t.co/wQO3RhpVxX 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 25, 2024

item.title: 在一些人看来，澳大利亚的野马是牧场文化的最后遗存，这种文化在高原地区受到保护时被摧毁了。但随着野马数量的增长，政客们正在打击野马 👇 。
item.description:
To some, Australia’s brumbies are a last vestige of a ranching culture destroyed when the high country was protected. But as their population grows, politicians are cracking down on the wild horses https://t.co/HYMsnYAzPS 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 25, 2024

item.title: 经过四个多月的战争，加沙的 36 家医院中只有四分之一在运营，而且只是部分运营。医疗系统的崩溃将使这一局面更加难以扭转 👇。
item.description:
After more than four months of war, only a quarter of Gaza’s 36 hospitals are operating—and those only partially.

The war has already rendered much of the strip uninhabitable. The collapse of its health system will make that even harder to reverse https://t.co/wWU5S64OAM 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 25, 2024

item.title: 雷达天文学家正在游说开发一种功能强大的新工具，以便跟踪和了解离地球最近的小行星--尤其是有朝一日可能撞击人类母星的小行星 👇。
item.description:
Radar astronomers are lobbying for a powerful new tool that would be able to track and understand the asteroids nearest Earth—especially any that might one day hit humanity’s home planet https://t.co/7XbvWbL06D 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 25, 2024

item.title: 长期以来，教育一直是数字化的落后者。人工智能能否最终改变这一现状？请听 @alice_fulwood, @Birdyword 和 @TomLeeDevlin 的 "Money Talks": 🎧
item.description:
Education has long been a digital laggard. Could AI finally change that? Listen to “Money Talks” with @alice_fulwood, @Birdyword and @TomLeeDevlin: https://t.co/LyLssgHmQF 🎧

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 25, 2024

item.title: 为什么人过中年，越老越快乐 👇
item.description:
Why, beyond middle age, people get happier as they get older https://t.co/rJCW0gkfXk 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 25, 2024

item.title: EssilorLuxottica 希望成为智能眼镜领域的领导者。这个想法并不新鲜，但很多乐观主义者认为，智能眼镜的时代已经到来。第二个大想法更具个性化： 👇。
item.description:
EssilorLuxottica wants to be the leader in smart glasses. The idea is not new, but plenty of optimists think that the moment for smart spectacles has arrived. The second big idea is more personal: https://t.co/VgMQralXhg 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 25, 2024

item.title: 美国的大学在学习责任和社会正义之间徘徊，而这是任何一位校长都难以解决的矛盾。这为所有组织提供了更广泛的借鉴👇。
item.description:
America’s universities are torn between their responsibilities to learning and social justice—and that is a tension any president will find hard to resolve. This carries wider lessons for all organisations https://t.co/MAqC6clGC2 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 25, 2024

item.title: 异教正在兴起。这一切都源于《柳条人》。除了人祭之外，这部电影还让受古老传统影响的生活显得颇具吸引力👇。
item.description:
Paganism is on the rise. It all started with “The Wicker Man”. Human sacrifice apart, the film made a life shaped by ancient traditions seem rather appealing https://t.co/LFxiAhyjzs 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 25, 2024

item.title: 重塑中国龙形象的民族主义努力
item.description:
A nationalist effort to rebrand the Chinese dragon https://t.co/u3cgga2Mg1

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 25, 2024

item.title: 他信-西那瓦加入泰国建制派
item.description:
Thaksin Shinawatra joins Thailand’s establishment https://t.co/0a65PbTeBB

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 25, 2024

item.title: 很少有剧集能像《王冠》这样稳定地刺激观众，其中很多内容都是无稽之谈。历史可能是它的问题所在，但历史也是它的魅力所在👇。
item.description:
Few shows irritate audiences as reliably as “The Crown”, much of which is nonsense. History might be problematic for it—but history is also part of the appeal https://t.co/uDEGFZoiLf 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 25, 2024

item.title: 为什么地处内陆的埃斯瓦提尼有船舶注册处？像它这样的国家可能会助长 "黑暗船队 "的发展 👇
item.description:
Why does landlocked Eswatini have a ship registry? Countries like it may be helping to fuel the growth of a “dark fleet” https://t.co/fm2hMvkzSR 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 25, 2024

item.title: 马航 MH17 航班到底发生了什么👇？
item.description:
What really happened to Flight MH17 https://t.co/LabGsk7T6t 👇

item.description:
The most expensive city in Europe is also the most expensive in the world—tied with Singapore https://t.co/dHFVeCjvtC 👇

What Javier Milei could learn from Peru’s economic successes https://t.co/h6KSWD3vlH

How working from home is reshaping Canary Wharf https://t.co/luPDLkNqEQ

The age of the unicorn is over https://t.co/xIVtho7be6
